seo.title: Laurito Beach guide
seo.description: Choose between Da Adolfo and Tre Ville, learn how the shuttle boats work, and plan a stress-free beach day in Laurito.

intro: Laurito is a pocket-sized cove tucked between Positano and Praiano. Two beach clubs — Da Adolfo and Villa Tre Ville — dominate the shoreline, leaving just a sliver of public sand. The reward is west-facing sunshine, iconic lunch spots, and a quieter atmosphere than Spiaggia Grande.
Use this guide to decide which club suits your style, understand how the water taxis operate, and map out the bus-and-stairs route back to Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Why Laurito is worth the effort
body: Laurito sits just outside Positano’s centre, so crowds thin out compared with Spiaggia Grande. Sun hits the deck until early evening, the water stays calm for swimming, and the cliff backdrop makes for classic Amalfi Coast photos.
You will need either a confirmed reservation or patience for the tiny free strip, but once you are settled it is one of the most relaxed spots within a short ride of Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Layout and who runs what
body: The cove splits into three zones. A narrow public area sits on the far right for those who bring their own towels. Villa Tre Ville’s club occupies the central decks with terracotta loungers, while Da Adolfo operates the left-hand side with wooden beds and the restaurant terrace.
All guests arrive by boat or via the steep stairway from the SITA bus stop. Expect to queue at peak times because both clubs control access to most of the shoreline.

sections.title: Villa Tre Ville beach club
body: Villa Tre Ville hosts a boutique club with limited loungers, attentive service, and pricing to match. Expect premium day beds, à la carte dining, and prosecco served to your chair.
Reservations run through the hotel concierge. Seats can exceed €200 for two in high season, but include towels, showers, and return boat service to Spiaggia Grande.
Late afternoon is particularly scenic; staff often arrange sunset spritz tastings before the final shuttle back to Positano.

sections.title: Da Adolfo beach club
body: Da Adolfo is famous for its grilled mozzarella on lemon leaves and relaxed, bohemian vibe. Booking is notoriously difficult — they reply slowly, and day-of slots go to returning guests first.

If you cannot secure a reservation, arrive early at Spiaggia Grande and ask to join the Da Adolfo water taxi as a standby guest. Once at the dock, staff will add you to their waitlist for any no-shows.
Lounger packages hover around €50–€70 for two people including the shuttle. Lunch mains run €18–€26 and the kitchen stays open through late afternoon.

sections.title: Logistics, tickets, and getting back
body: Water taxis for both clubs depart from the small pier on Spiaggia Grande. Boats typically run every 30 minutes from 09:30 until early afternoon, then resume returns around 15:00. Keep an eye on the chalkboard at the dock for changes when seas are rough.

Prefer public transport? Follow our %LINK:lauritoBeachBusDown|bus guide% for the outbound journey and %LINK:lauritoBeachBusBack|return guide% for the climb back. Buy your bus tickets before leaving town — there is nowhere to purchase them at Laurito.

On the way home, the coastal bus towards Sorrento or Positano stops beside the staircase entrance. Services thin out after 19:00, so confirm the last departure or budget for a taxi arranged via the hostel.

essentials: Reservations are essential for both clubs in summer; walk-ins only succeed before 10:00.
Tiny public section fills quickly — arrive with your own umbrella and mat if you plan to use it.
Return boats leave mid-afternoon; have the bus backup ready for evening plans.
typicalCosts: Da Adolfo lounger set for two: €50–€70 including shuttle boat.
Villa Tre Ville premium deck for two: €180–€220 with towels and concierge service.
Lunch mains at either club: €18–€30, cocktails €12–€15, bottled water €3–€4.
tips: Screenshot confirmation emails — mobile signal fades near the dock.
Pack reef-safe sunscreen and water shoes; the shoreline mixes pebbles and rock slabs.
Review our %LINK:positanoBeaches|Positano beaches overview% to compare Laurito with other coves.
warnings: Rough seas pause shuttle boats; staff will text updates but the bus may be your only route back.
No ATMs or shops at the cove — bring cash or cards for meals and extras.
The stairway is steep with uneven steps; plan breaks and wear grippy footwear.

faqs.q: Can I use the public section?
a: You can, but space is extremely limited. Bring everything you need, including shade and water, and arrive before 09:30 to claim a spot.

faqs.q: How late do the boats run?
a: Most return shuttles finish by 18:00 in summer, earlier in shoulder season. Always confirm the last departure on arrival and have the bus timetable saved as a backup.
